Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the step-parent needs to provide it
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story: I sit at the kitchen table, headset on, laptop open, the hum of the call center software in my ears. My stepson, Jamie, is in the next room, his voice drifting in as he asks for help with his homework. I glance at the bills stacked beside me—electricity, groceries, rent. I know I have to keep this job; we need every paycheck to keep the lights on and food in the fridge. My manager expects me to handle every call smoothly, to stick to the script, to never let a customer’s question throw me off. Most days, it’s easy—just a few objections, nothing I can’t handle. But today, Jamie’s math homework is due tomorrow, and he’s struggling. He calls out again, a little more desperate. I feel the pressure mounting—my family needs me to be present, to help, to care. But the call queue is full, and my supervisor is watching my stats. I can’t be in two places at once. My heart pounds as I hear the next call connect, and Jamie’s voice overlaps with the customer’s greeting.
